bestBHT.bht: As believers, it is our responsibility to consider the weaknesses and scruples of others rather than seeking to please ourselves. We, who are morally strong, must bear the burden of patiently enduring with those who are weak. This involves not only tolerating their weaknesses, but assisting and helping them. We should refrain from using our Christian liberty in things indifferent if it offends or causes stumbling to others. Our focus should be on the welfare and edification of our fellow believers, rather than satisfying our own desires and judgments.

Henry Alford: By the words we that are strong, the Apostle includes himself among the strong.
The infirmities are general, not merely referring to the scruples before treated.
The Apostle includes himself among the strong, as indeed he before indicated.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: We then that are strong—on such points as have been discussed, the abolition of the Jewish distinction of meats and days under the Gospel."
Ought . . . not to please ourselves—ought to think less of what we may lawfully do than of how our conduct will affect others.
Albert Barnes: Ought to bear... to endure patiently, not to contend with.
Not to make it our main object to gratify our own wills.
We are not to make our own happiness or gratification the standard of our conduct, but are to seek the welfare of others.
Marvin Vincent: Infirmities [ασθενηματα] Only here in the New Testament.
John Calvin: The stronger then anyone is in Christ, the more bound he is to bear with the weak."

By saying that a Christian ought not to please himself, he intimates, that he ought not to be bent on satisfying himself, as they are wont to be, who are content with their own judgment, and heedlessly neglect others."
The duty is not merely to bear with or tolerate weaknesses, but to help and assist the weak and the feeble to carry them.
Philip Schaff: Ought to bear, as a burden is borne.
He is indeed strong who can thus bear.
Such moral selfishness is involved in disregarding the weaknesses of the brethren who have false scruples.
Archibald T. Robertson: He means the morally strong as in 2 Corinthians 12:10; 2 Corinthians 13:9, not the mighty as in 1 Corinthians 1:26.
The weaknesses' (cf. ασθενων in Romans 14:1; Romans 14:2), the scruples 'of the not strong' (των αδυνατων).
Not to please ourselves (μη εαυτοις αρεσκειν). Precisely Paul's picture of his own conduct in 1 Corinthians 10:33.
John Gill: They are not to be treated as wicked men, but as weak brethren.
Moreover, they are to be complied with in cases not sinful.
Stronger Christians should deny themselves the use of their Christian liberty in things indifferent, when they cannot make use of it without offence.
John Wesley: We who are strong — Of a clearer judgment, and free from these scruples.
And not to please ourselves — Without any regard to others.

bhtAttempts.bht: As believers, it is our responsibility to consider the weaknesses and scruples of others rather than seeking to please ourselves. We, who are morally strong, must bear the burden of patiently enduring with those who are weak. This involves not only tolerating their weaknesses, but assisting and helping them. We should refrain from using our Christian liberty in things indifferent if it offends or causes stumbling to others. Our focus should be on the welfare and edification of our fellow believers, rather than satisfying our own desires and judgments. Ultimately, the more we grow in Christ, the greater our commitment to bearing with the weak becomes.

As believers, we, including the Apostle himself, must bear the weaknesses and scruples of others, not merely pleasing ourselves, but considering how our conduct impacts them. This means patiently enduring and assisting the weak, denying ourselves the use of Christian liberty when it offends or causes stumbling, and treating them as weak brethren, not as wicked individuals. Our focus should be on the welfare of others, rather than satisfying our own judgments and desires.

As believers, it is our responsibility to consider the weaknesses and scruples of others rather than seeking to please ourselves. We, who are morally strong, must bear the burden of patiently enduring with those who are weak. This involves not only tolerating their weaknesses, but assisting and helping them. We should refrain from using our Christian liberty in things indifferent if it offends or causes stumbling to others. Our focus should be on the welfare and edification of our fellow believers, rather than satisfying our own desires and judgments.

As believers, it is important for us to prioritize the needs and weaknesses of others over our own desires. We must bear the burden of patiently enduring with those who are weak, not seeking to please ourselves. This means assisting and helping them, refraining from actions that may cause offense or stumbling. Our focus should be on the well-being and growth of our fellow believers, rather than solely satisfying our own preferences and judgments.

We, who are strong, should not solely seek to please ourselves but should consider how our actions may affect others. This includes bearing with the weaknesses and scruples of those who are not as morally strong, rather than disregarding them. By doing this, we demonstrate our strength in Christ and fulfill our duty to assist and support our weaker brothers and sisters. It is not enough to simply tolerate their weaknesses, but we should actively help them carry their burdens. In doing so, we not only exemplify humility and selflessness, but we fulfill the commandment to love our neighbors as ourselves.
